title: 109_hr2753
content: The "Public Campaign Financing Act of 2005" establishes public funding for House of Representatives elections. Candidates qualify for funding by obtaining signatures of 3% of registered voters or being the candidate of a party that received over 25% of the vote in the previous election. Contributions to qualifying candidates are limited. The "Public Campaign Financing Act of 2005" limits House of Representatives candidates to accepting individual contributions of $100 per person per election cycle and requires at least 80% of contributions to come from the state where the congressional district is located. A qualifying House of Representatives candidate can use public funds for buying advertising space, producing advertisements, campaign software, printing campaign literature, telephone expenses, legal and accounting costs, and other campaign-related expenses. A qualifying House of Representatives candidate can use public funds for various campaign expenses such as legal and accounting costs, campaign employees' salaries, office equipment, supplies, travel, and food. However, public funds cannot be used for the candidate's salary or personal mortgages. The candidate will receive public funds equivalent to the cost of 2.5 hours of television commercial time in the district's media markets. The Commission determines funds for candidates based on media market costs and a multiplier of media points. Funds can be used for any campaign purpose specified. Disbursements are made upon evidence of eligible expenses, not exceeding 4 months before the election. The maximum public funding for qualifying House of Representatives candidates is $750,000, indexed for inflation every two years. Candidates must participate in at least 2 televised debates and accept advertising from radio and television stations. Radio and television stations must accept advertising orders paid under this title until it reaches 40% of total advertising time. Stations are subject to random checks to ensure correct advertising charges. License renewal and issuance are contingent on compliance with these rules. SEC. 507 defines terms related to House of Representatives candidates, qualifying candidates, and congressional district media markets. SEC. 3 outlines reporting requirements for radio and television stations accepting advertising orders under this title. Compliance is necessary for license renewal and issuance. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to allow State committees to file reports with the Commission if they contain the same information. Additional reporting requirements for authorized committees are also outlined. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include disbursements for various elections by authorized committees. Additionally, reporting requirements for operating expenditures are updated to include the election to which the expenditure relates. SEC. 4. REPORTING OF ELECTION ACTIVITY OF PERSONS OTHER THAN POLITICAL PARTIES. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require persons not covered by section 323 to file a statement if they make disbursements for Federal election activities exceeding $2,000. Statements must be filed 48 hours before the disbursements are made or within 14 days of the election if required. An additional statement must be filed for each additional disbursement of $2,000 made by individuals not covered by section 323. The statement should be filed with the appropriate authorities and include information prescribed by the Commission, such as the purpose of the disbursement. The authorities must transmit the statement to the Commission within specific timeframes. The Commission must transmit statements within specific timeframes to candidates, political parties, or state committees regarding disbursements. The Commission can make determinations on disbursements and notify relevant parties within 24 hours. Exceptions apply to candidates and their authorized committees. The Federal Election Commission must transmit statements promptly to candidates, political parties, or state committees regarding disbursements, with exceptions for candidates and their authorized committees. SEC. 5. CONTRIBUTIONS THROUGH INTERMEDIARIES AND CONDUITS. Section 315(a)(8) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include regulations regarding contributions made through intermediaries or conduits to political candidates. Contributions must be reported to the Commission by the intermediary or conduit, disclosing the original source and intended recipient of the contribution. Contributions made through intermediaries or conduits to political candidates must be reported to the Commission. If the contributions are in the form of a check made payable to the intermediary or conduit, they will be treated as contributions from the intermediary or conduit to the candidate. The intermediary or conduit could be a political committee, party, or a person required to report under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 and the Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938 require lobbyists and foreign agents to report their activities. Contributions arranged to be made include those delivered directly or indirectly to a candidate. Contributions can be made indirectly to a candidate through a facilitator or at a fundraising event sponsored by an intermediary. Fundraising efforts by another candidate or officeholder are allowed, as well as individual solicitation of contributions. Contributions can be made indirectly to a candidate through a facilitator or at a fundraising event sponsored by an intermediary. Fundraising efforts by another candidate or officeholder are allowed, as well as individual solicitation of contributions. The candidate must ensure that they do not accept contributions in their own name that actually come from other individuals. The amendments made by this Act will be effective for elections after December 31, 2006.
